reference-answers: The pericardium is a thin, dense sac that separates the heart from other organs and also prevents it from being displaced and stretched too much.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: How does blood move in the chambers of the heart?
reference-answers: The right and left halves of the heart do not communicate with each other. The chambers of the right part contain only venous blood, and the chambers of the left - only arterial.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What is the name of the valve between the left atrium and the left ventricle?

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What are the two main parts of the circulatory system?

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What are the two large parts of the circulatory system?
reference-answers: The circulatory system in the human body is divided into two large parts - the large and small circles of blood circulation.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What happens to venous blood once it enters the lungs?
reference-answers: Venous blood is transported through the vessels to the lungs. Once in the lungs, it is saturated with oxygen and gives off carbon dioxide, after which it turns into arterial blood.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What are the main properties of cardiac muscle?
reference-answers: Cardiac muscle works continuously throughout a person's life. That is why it has certain structural features and specific properties, which allowed it to be distinguished as a separate type of muscle tissue.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What happens during the cardiac cycle?
reference-answers: The heart can work continuously for many years due to the fact that its work is organized in the form of a cycle.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What is the main engine responsible for blood flow through the vessels?
reference-answers: The heart is the main engine of blood flow through the vessels.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: How long does the atria rest in one cardiac cycle?
reference-answers: If you look at the time taken by individual phases of the cardiac cycle, you can see that out of 0.8 seconds of the entire cycle, the atria rest for 0.7 seconds.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: Why is it important to give the heart's muscles time to recover?
reference-answers: The correct distribution of the phases of contraction and relaxation of individual parts of the heart, the body manages to provide enough time for the heart muscle to recover during its work.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What happens to the body if the heart stops working?
reference-answers: It cannot stop, as this will cause the cessation of metabolism and lead to the death of a person.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: How often do the atria and ventricles rest during the cardiac cycle?
reference-answers: the atria rest for 0.7 seconds, and the ventricles for 0.5 seconds out of a total of 0.8 seconds

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What ensures the movement of blood through the vessels?
reference-answers: They perform different functions, which determines the differences in their structure (Fig. 19.1). Capillaries are responsible for the exchange between blood and tissues, so their walls are thin. And veins collect blood from all over the body to transport it to the heart. It is very important for them to ensure that blood moves in only one direction, which is possible due to the presence of special valves.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What determines the differences in structure among arteries, veins, and capillaries?

reference-answers: However, health problems in a person can also occur in the case of too low pressure. If a person's pressure is constantly higher than 140 over 90 or lower than 90 over 60, this is a reason to consult a doctor.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What happens when the heart contracts and pushes blood into the arteries?
reference-answers: Blood pressure is highest during systole, and lowest during diastole. The value of blood pressure is an indicator of the condition of the heart in particular and the circulatory system in general, so doctors often measure it when examining patients.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What happens to the pulse when measuring blood pressure?
reference-answers: During contraction, the heart not only pushes blood into the vessels, but also causes periodic oscillations of the walls of the arteries, which are synchronous with the contractions of the heart.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What is the purpose of measuring pulse pressure?
reference-answers: The difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure is called pulse pressure. If the pulse pressure is less than 20 mm Hg., the heart will not receive enough blood for its work.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What happens to blood when it passes through the vessels?
reference-answers: The harder it is for blood to pass through the vessels, the higher the arterial pressure.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What is the portal vein's function?
reference-answers: It collects blood from the stomach and intestines and carries it to the liver.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: Why is a tourniquet applied below the site of venous bleeding?
reference-answers: the case of venous bleeding, the tourniquet is applied below the site of hemorrhage, because it is from there that the blood moves through the veins.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: Why is a tourniquet not used for capillary bleeding?
reference-answers: Capillary bleeding is not as intense as arterial or venous bleeding, and often stops on its own. In the case of capillary bleeding, an ordinary sterile bandage can be used.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What type of vessel is responsible for the exchange of substances between the blood and tissues?
reference-answers: There are three types of blood vessels in the human body - arteries, veins and capillaries. Arteries carry blood from the heart, veins - to the heart, and capillaries ensure the exchange of substances between the blood and tissues.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: Why is a tourniquet applied above the bleeding site for arterial bleeding?
reference-answers: In case of bleeding due to injury to the extremities of the head, do not forget that during arterial bleeding, the tourniquet is applied above the bleeding site, and in the case of venous bleeding - below.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What is the importance of providing first aid in case of bleeding?
reference-answers: First aid in case of bleeding should be provided taking into account which type of vessel was damaged.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: Why is it crucial to seek medical care quickly after a critical situation such as a heart attack or stroke?
reference-answers: The earlier the care is provided, the greater the chances of a positive result of the doctors' work.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What are some risk factors for cardiovascular diseases?
reference-answers: Risk factors for cardiovascular diseases may include: failure to follow the rules of a healthy lifestyle (smoking, alcohol abuse, insufficient physical activity), excess body weight, high blood pressure, constant stress, etc.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: Why does regular physical activity facilitate the work of the heart?
reference-answers: Regular physical activity, thanks to which other muscles of the body are strengthened and work better. And they, in turn, during contraction, contribute to the movement of blood through the veins to the heart.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What is the effect of passive smoking on coronary heart disease?
reference-answers: Even passive smoking can cause this disease, when a person does not smoke himself, but is often among smokers and simply inhales tobacco smoke.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: Why does the movement of blood in veins slow down due to insufficient physical activity?
reference-answers: Due to insufficient physical activity and a sedentary lifestyle, the movement of blood in the veins slows down. Its reverse movement is impossible due to the valves in these vessels.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What is carried by the medulla of the urethra?

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: How does heat loss occur through the skin?
reference-answers: Evaporation of water excreted through the sweat glands causes heat loss, which is also very important, since heat is one of the metabolic products and its excess in the body is undesirable.

reference-answers: There are nerve endings in the walls of the bladder, which, when it is stretched (when it is filled with urine), send a signal to the central nervous system.

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What is the regulation mechanism of kidney function?

ukr-biology/book02/topic04- /text.en.txt.question: What is the difference between ascending and descending infections?
reference-answers: If the infection first gets into the urethra, causes its inflammation and spreads upwards - to the bladder, ureters and kidneys, then it is called ascending. If the infection first gets into the urinary system through other channels, then it is called descending.

reference-answers: For example, when the body needs to give off excess heat, the vessels expand, more blood flows through them, the skin heats up, giving off more heat.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: What is the main idea behind Bergmann's rule?
reference-answers: According to Bergmann's rule, the body size of animals of the same species (or several closely related species of the same genus) is larger in the colder parts of its range and smaller in the warmer parts.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: What is the main idea behind Allen's rule?
reference-answers: According to Allen's rule, the smallest size of protruding body parts are in animals that live in the coldest regions, and the largest - in the inhabitants of the warmest regions.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: What is Allen's rule?
reference-answers: Allen's rule, like Bergman's rule, also reflects the adaptations of animals to heat exchange with the environment.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: What is a preadaptation?
reference-answers: Adaptations of living organisms do not arise from nothing. Their development is based on the structures and capabilities that these organisms already have.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: What is the purpose of fins in brush-footed fish before they adapted to life on land?
reference-answers: In the process of adaptation of brush-footed fish to life on land, the fins lost their old main function. And the auxiliary function became a new main one for them.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: Why do giraffes have longer necks than okapis?
reference-answers: An adaptation to this type of nutrition was the elongation of the neck. However, the degree of elongation depended on the shape and size of the crowns of the trees whose leaves the animals consumed.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: What determines the number of legs in the descendants of fish that adapted to life on land?
reference-answers: The number of fins also determined the number of legs in the descendants of these fish. They all became four-legged.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: What is an example of a postadaptation?
reference-answers: Adaptations that have arisen in the organism are not complete, they are constantly being improved. Evolutionary changes that improve the already existing adaptations of organisms are called postadaptations.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: How do plants adapt to different environmental conditions?
reference-answers: Plants in the forest can adapt to different options for environmental conditions: either they become tall and occupy the upper tiers of the forest, or low and occupy its lower tiers.

reference-answers: The conditions of existence in different places are different.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: When did Charles Darwin study Galapagos finches?
reference-answers: They are often called Darwin's finches, because Charles Darwin studied them.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: Approximately how many years ago did the ancestral species of Galapagos finches reach the Galapagos Islands?

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: How did the birds adapt to different living conditions on each of the islands?

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: What type of adaptation did orangutans and gibbons develop?
reference-answers: At the same time, gibbons developed a very specific way of moving through trees using their forelimbs - brachiation.

ukr-biology/book05/topic01-/text.en.txt.question: How did chimpanzees and gorillas adapt to different conditions?
reference-answers: Chimpanzees began to spend a lot of time not in trees, but on the ground. And gorillas almost completely switched to a terrestrial lifestyle.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What causes smog?
reference-answers: The formation of smog is caused by exhaust gases from transport and dust that rises during its movement, emissions from heating systems and industrial enterprises.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why should city dwellers limit their stay outdoors during smog?
reference-answers: To reduce the harmful effects of smog on the body, it is advisable to follow some recommendations: avoid walking in the morning, reduce your stay on the street during this period of the day;

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What international document aimed at regulating greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere was adopted in 1997?
reference-answers: Also in 1997, the Kyoto Protocol was adopted - an international document aimed at regulating greenhouse gas emissions into the atmosphere.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What are the main substances that enter the hydrosphere?
reference-answers: The main substances that enter the hydrosphere: clay, silt and other substances; petroleum products; salts of heavy metals; surfactants; pesticides; microorganisms (from food production and wastewater); radionuclides; household waste, polyethylene, etc.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the consequence of human influence on the hydrosphere that has affected the state of both aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems?
reference-answers: A large number of pollutants caused a mass death of organisms in fresh and salt water bodies. Both animals, plants and microorganisms died.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why is the shortage of drinking water a significant problem?
reference-answers: There is a lot of water on our planet. But most of it is salty or contained in glaciers of polar regions and mountainous areas. And for normal life and economic activity, people need fresh water.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What are the main substances that contribute to the growth and reproduction of algae in water bodies?
reference-answers: The reason for this effect is a large number of substances that enter water bodies as a result of anthropogenic activity and create good conditions for the growth and reproduction of algae. Such substances include compounds of Phosphorus, Nitrogen and Carbon.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What can happen to aquatic organisms as a result of water blooms?
reference-answers: This results in the death of many aquatic organisms from suffocation. Some algae can also release toxins into the water, which increases the scale of the death of organisms.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What causes water blooms and what color can they be?
reference-answers: The color of the water in the event of a bloom depends on which algae are multiplying.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What substances do plants and animals absorb from the soil?
reference-answers: Human impact on soils Soil pollution has become a significant problem for many regions of the planet.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What are some major causes of soil degradation?
reference-answers: Unsuccessful land reclamation often ends in soil salinization (Fig. 39.3, p. 144). Excessive grazing of livestock destroys the grass cover and causes the destruction of the fertile soil layer through erosion.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why is international cooperation needed for soil protection?
reference-answers: Soil protection requires international efforts, although it can be effective within the borders of one country. But soil degradation in other countries will still affect the situation, because countries with degraded soils will be threatened with famine.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is a result of hostilities on the environment?
reference-answers: The state of the soil is also adversely affected by hostilities. Explosives, which are widely used, enter the soil, because during any explosion, absolutely complete combustion of the explosive does not occur.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the basis of correct crop rotation?
reference-answers: The basis of correct crop rotation is the phenomenon of natural restoration of soil fertility.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why is the use of fertilizers important?
reference-answers: Their use creates optimal conditions for the vital activity of soil biocenosis and plant cultivation.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What types of fertilizers are used for agricultural purposes?
reference-answers: The use of rect fertilizers (both mineral and organic) is also important.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the primary reason for the extinction of the thylacine marsupial wolf?
reference-answers: The Tasmanian marsupial wolf was completely exterminated after a hundred years of settlement by white settlers, and farmers believed it could be a potential threat to sheep.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the impact of goats on island ecosystems?
reference-answers: Goats are excellent climbers, they climb trees and eat leaves. Excessive reproduction of this species without controlling predators has turned many islands into bare rocks with almost no vegetation.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: How did the introduction of non-native species affect island ecosystems?
reference-answers: People settled the islands and easily destroyed the small populations of local animal and plant species. Pigs, cats, dogs, rats destroyed bird nests, caught and ate adult animals of all local species.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What happens to islands with many goats due to excessive reproduction without controlling predators?
reference-answers: Excessive reproduction of this species without controlling predators has turned many islands into bare rocks with almost no vegetation, which led to the devastation and death of other species.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is reacclimatization?
reference-answers: If the organism once lived in this region and its introduction was repeated, then such a process is called reacclimatization.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why is biodiversity valuable to humans?
reference-answers: The presence of a large number of species makes connections in ecosystems more diverse. Diverse connections and branched trophic webs increase the resistance of ecosystems to external influences.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the main reason for reacclimatization?
reference-answers: The main reason for reacclimatization is an attempt to restore lost biodiversity.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What happened to the ginkgo tree?
reference-answers: But this plant once almost completely died out and has survived only in artificial cultivation.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why was the Mauritian dodo extinct?
reference-answers: It took less than a hundred years to exterminate it. This large (up to 20 kg) flightless representative of the pigeon family was hunted for meat.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why is it important to preserve habitats and not just species, when it comes to nature conservation?
reference-answers: If you preserve the habitats, but destroy the species that this animal feeds on, or bring emissions into the water it drinks to a toxic level, the result will be the same - extinction.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the main idea of sustainable development?
reference-answers: The main idea of the Concept was that development should meet the needs of the present generation without harming future generations.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why can deforestation of the Amazon in Brazil affect the environmental situation in Europe?
reference-answers: Why can deforestation of the Amazon in Brazil affect the environmental situation in Europe?

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why is sustainable development important?
reference-answers: After all, we cannot leave future generations without any resources for life.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the goal of using fertilizers in agriculture?
reference-answers: But the ways of applying fertilizers can be different. And the effectiveness of the application can be different.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the most effective way to implement the Sustainable Development Concept?
reference-answers: The implementation of sustainable development tasks can be carried out at different levels.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Who must understand the need for sorting garbage and energy-saving technologies in order for them to be implemented?
reference-answers: It is impossible to implement energy-saving technologies if voters do not support those politicians who want to adopt the relevant laws.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What level of cooperation is required to successfully implement sustainable development tasks?
reference-answers: Only the scale of this cooperation differs. The simplest cooperation takes place at the family level, when people jointly make decisions about separate garbage collection or insulation of their own home.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is required for successful implementation of sustainable development tasks at a local community level?
reference-answers: But the results will also be more extensive. It already becomes possible when local governments and the interaction of a large number of people are involved.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What level of decision-making requires the participation of local governments and a large number of people for success?
reference-answers: In this case, success is impossible without the participation of local governments and the interaction of a large number of people.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the phrase "Ignorance of the law does not exempt from responsibility" referring to?
reference-answers: The phrase Ignorance of the law does not exempt from responsibility is particularly relevant when considering ecological knowledge.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What was a consequence of trying to eradicate birds of prey in the Soviet Union?
reference-answers: The destruction of birds of prey caused the massive reproduction of rodents, the number of which they controlled.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What was needed to solve the problem of prickly pear cactus in Australia?
reference-answers: The problem was solved only by importing from America a natural regulator of the number of prickly pears - the cactus moth.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What was imported from America to control the spread of prickly pears in Australia?
reference-answers: The problem was solved only by importing from America a natural regulator of the number of prickly pears - the cactus moth.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why did Australian farmers sow clover in their fields?
reference-answers: To better feed the imported livestock, Australian farmers began to sow clover. But the clover in their fields did not want to reproduce, although it grew well.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why didn't bees pollinate the clover flowers?
reference-answers: Bees could not do this. Bumblebees also had to be imported to Australia.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is ecological thinking?
reference-answers: Ecological thinking Therefore, without comprehensive knowledge of ecology, human interaction with natural ecosystems can cause real ecological disasters. ... Ecological thinking is the consideration of phenomena and events and decision-making taking into account the interactions of man and humanity with the natural environment based on diverse and deep knowledge about the environment and a responsible attitude to nature and human health.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the effect of ecological thinking on decision-making?
reference-answers: Ecological thinking allows us to understand that all organisms and processes on our planet are interconnected. Accordingly, the need for international cooperation to solve environmental problems becomes clear, because it is impossible to do this alone. Ecological thinking is necessary for critical perception of information. It allows us to draw the right conclusions and make adequate decisions.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is ecological thinking?
reference-answers: ecological thinking is necessary for critical perception of information.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: How can humans destroy the conditions for their existence on Earth?
reference-answers: Ecosystems that are comfortable for humanity to live in can be destroyed quite easily by humans themselves.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What was the consequence of blocking the Dnieper riverbed and building dams?
reference-answers: The dams built blocked the Dnieper riverbed, hid the Dnieper rapids and provided many metallurgical enterprises with electricity (Fig. 43.3). But the consequence of this was flooding large areas with fertile soils, the need to resettle a large number of settlements, the difficulty of the Dnieper self-purification processes and obstacles to fish spawning in the upper reaches of the river.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: Why would destroying all dams at once cause ecological harm?
reference-answers: Yes, if all the dams of power plants are eliminated at the same time now, nothing good will happen to local ecosystems. Local ecosystems have long adapted to the existing groundwater level. After the dams are destroyed, this level will drop significantly. The result will be a massive drying out of forests throughout the Dnieper basin, because the trees simply will not have time to rebuild their root system to the new location of the water horizons.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What was the problem caused by the use of freon as a coolant in refrigerators?
reference-answers: A classic example of the implementation of ecological thinking was the understanding of the role of refrigerators in the emergence of the problem of the ozone layer of the atmosphere. The use of freon as a coolant turned out to be a very convenient technological solution.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What was the result of replacing Freon with other coolants?
reference-answers: The solution was found by replacing Freon with other coolants.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What are some types of environmental pollution?
reference-answers: Physical, Chemical, Biological

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the purpose of sustainable development?
reference-answers: reduction of CO2 emissions, environmental protection and preservation

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What are some common methods of waste disposal?
reference-answers: household waste recycling, poor disposal

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: When did scientific methods become used in breeding?
reference-answers: Scientific methods were not used at first stages of selection, but this was compensated by the rich practical experience of people who had been engaged in this all their lives, and the considerable duration of the selection process.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: When did genetics emerge as a theoretical basis for breeding?
reference-answers: It was then that selection received a theoretical basis for its work.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What is the main goal of selection tasks in Selection studies?
reference-answers: Selection tasks are aimed at meeting the needs of human life: obtaining high-quality agricultural products, in particular food products and industrial crops.

ukr-biology/book05/topic04- /text.en..question: What was the result of the 'Green Revolution' in world agriculture?
reference-answers: The result of selection work was the creation of thousands of varieties of cultivated plants and dozens and hundreds of breeds of domestic animals. 163

reference-answers: Ions and how are they formed?

reference-answers: What type of chemical bond is in a water molecule?

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What types of compounds are important for living organisms?
reference-answers: Inorganic compounds can be found in living organisms both in dissolved form (in the form of ions) and in insoluble form. Dissolved forms are represented by many salts.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the reason for the high surface tension of water?
reference-answers: It has a high surface tension.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is water's role in maintaining body temperature?
reference-answers: The thermoregulatory function of water is extremely important for maintaining the body temperature of organisms. When, for example, a person sweats, the water that evaporates lowers his body temperature.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What substance do plants use to maintain their shape?
reference-answers: Plants maintain the shape of leaves and grassy stems due to increased pressure in water-filled cells.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What are some examples of organic substances?
reference-answers: Proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, nucleic acids, water, minerals (mainly salts), acids They are contained in the bodies of both inanimate and living nature, more than inorganic ones.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is unique about the structure of organic molecules compared to inorganic substances?
reference-answers: Features of the structure of molecules of organic substances differ from each other in the number of links in the carbon chain.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the typical size range for large molecules (macromolecules)?
reference-answers: Macromolecules have a mass of more than 1000 Da.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: Why are silicon-based chains considered to be much worse than carbon-based chains?
reference-answers: Silicon forms much weaker chemical bonds due to its larger radius.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What are biopolymers?
reference-answers: Polymers that are produced by living organisms are called biopolymers.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: How many monomers can be in a biopolymer?
reference-answers: The number of monomers in biopolymers can vary: from one or two dozen for some proteins and carbohydrates to hundreds of thousands and even millions.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the main structure of protein molecules?
reference-answers: Proteins are large organic molecules, consisting of monomers - amino acids, which are connected in the form of a chain.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What are the two groups of atoms attached to one carbon atom in amino acids?
reference-answers: These groups of atoms are attached to one carbon atom. In amino acids that are not part of proteins (and such also occur in nature), these groups can also be attached to different carbon atoms.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the purpose of the peptide bond in a protein molecule?
reference-answers: The primary structure of a protein ensures the combination of amino acids into one chain. This chain has a linear structure (i.e., it has the form of a thread). The bond that connects amino acid molecules is called a peptide bond, and the chain itself is called a polypeptide.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of chemical bonds and interactions help maintain the structure of a protein molecule?
reference-answers: To maintain such a structure, or to stabilize it, there are certain chemical bonds and interactions. They ensure the constancy of its configuration, and therefore its functioning.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the relationship between the -helical and -pleated structures?
reference-answers: In one protein molecule, different parts of it can have different versions of the secondary structure. In some parts, it can have a folded -helical structure , and in others, a helical structure.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the most complex level of structural organization in protein molecules?
reference-answers: There are four levels of structural organization of a protein molecule. The primary structure is the simplest, the quaternary structure is the most complex.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What forms the secondary structure of a protein?
reference-answers: the folding of the -pleated structure of the molecule into a more compact structure.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: How do different parts of a protein molecule have different versions of secondary structure?
reference-answers: In one protein molecule, different parts of it can have different versions of the secondary structure.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of bonds are formed between amino acid residues to stabilize the tertiary structure of a protein?
reference-answers: This is achieved by stabilizing the protein molecule in space using hydrogen, ionic, disulfide bonds and hydrophobic interactions.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of bond is formed between radicals of amino acid cysteine due to the interaction of Sulfur atoms?
reference-answers: The formation of disulfide bonds, or disulfide bridges, is of greater importance .

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of bond occurs between radicals of hydrophobic amino acids?
reference-answers: Hydrophobic interaction occurs between radicals of hydrophobic amino acids.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What happens to hydrophobic interaction between radicals of hydrophobic amino acids when a protein molecule is in an aqueous solution?
reference-answers: Such radicals often accumulate together when a protein molecule is in an aqueous solution. Thus, hydrophobic radicals hide inside the molecule, and hydrophilic radicals are located outside, in contact with the aqueous environment.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What are the two large groups of proteins according to their composition?
reference-answers: Proteins can be divided into two large groups according to their composition - simple and complex.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is a prosthetic group in complex proteins?
reference-answers: Complex proteins (proteids), in addition to amino acid residues, also contain a non-protein part - a prosthetic group.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the difference between globular and fibrillar protein molecules?
reference-answers: Globular protein molecules have the appearance of a lump. Fibrillar protein molecules have the appearance of a thread.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the function of proteins in living organisms?
reference-answers: Almost all functions of living organisms are to one degree or another related to the work of certain groups of proteins.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What are protein hormones and their role?
reference-answers: Protein hormones are important regulators of metabolic processes in the body.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What do proteins provide for oxygen transport?
reference-answers: Proteins provide the transport of oxygen, fatty acids, lipids and other compounds in the body.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the role of enzymes in metabolic processes?
reference-answers: Enzymes are needed to carry out metabolic processes in the cell. Without them, metabolic reactions proceed extremely slowly. And often, these reactions do not occur at all without enzymes.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is unique about an enzyme's spatial structure?
reference-answers: The secret is in their spatial structure. Any enzyme is a chain of amino acids that is folded in a certain way in space.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the spatial arrangement that creates the active center of an enzyme?
reference-answers: The folding of the chain occurs in such a way that the amino acid radicals form a unique structure  the active center of the enzyme.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the role of cofactors in enzymes?
reference-answers: In some cases, a non-protein component is also required for the enzyme to work. This is a compound (called a cofactor) that joins the enzyme and also participates in the process of catalyzing the reaction.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of carbohydrates are biopolymers?
reference-answers: A significant part of carbohydrates is biopolymers (such as starch, cellulose, glycogen). Such biopolymers are called polysaccharides.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of monosaccharide does glucose contain?
reference-answers: Cells of all living organisms Ribose Linear or ring molecule, contains 5 carbon atoms

reference-answers: Glycogen Glucose Mushrooms and animals Insoluble compound, not sweet to taste A highly branched biopolymer molecule. One molecule can contain up to 50,000 monomers

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What functions do lipids perform in the human body?
reference-answers: They can also perform structural (cellulose, chitin) and storage (starch, glycogen) functions.

What are phospholipid molecules made of?
reference-answers: Phospholipid molecules have two properties. On the one hand, their molecules are hydrophilic, and on the other hand, they are hydrophobic.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of molecule does a wax contain?
reference-answers: Waxes are compounds of fatty acids with other alcohols that have long molecules and only one OH group.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: How do lipids contribute to the structure of cell membranes?
reference-answers: The structural function is performed by triglycerides, which form the basis of cell membranes.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is adipose tissue used for?
reference-answers: Such a layer retains heat well, because adipose tissue is a good heat insulator.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: Why do animals store lipids in their bodies?
reference-answers: This is why camels (Fig. 7.6), which live in deserts, store lipids in their bodies.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What are the main components of cell membranes?
reference-answers: They are important components of metabolism (vitamin A) and the basis of cell membranes (triglycerides).

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What are the five types of nucleotides?
reference-answers: Depending on which nitrogenous base is part of the nucleotide, there are five types of nucleotides: thymidylic (base - thymine), cytidylic (base - cytosine), uridylic (base - uracil), adenylic (base - adenine), guanylic (base - guanine).

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What are the nitrogenous bases of DNA nucleotides?
reference-answers: DNA nucleotides consist of the monosaccharide deoxyribose and four nitrogenous basesadenine, thymine, cytosine, and guanine.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What are the hydrogen bonds between RNA nucleotides?
reference-answers: Three such bonds are formed between guanine and cytosine, and two between adenine and thymine or adenine and uracil.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the principle of complementarity in DNA molecules?
reference-answers: Opposite each nucleotide of one chain is the nucleotide that corresponds to it. Opposite adenyl is thymidyl, and opposite cytidylic is guanyl.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is a characteristic of RNA molecules?
reference-answers: RNA molecule usually consists of one chain of nucleotides, different fragments of which form hydrogen bonds with each other.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What is the relationship between nucleotides and orthophosphate acid residues?
reference-answers: From one to three such residues can be attached to a nucleotide.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: Why do enzymes need energy from ATP molecules?
reference-answers: In order for enzymes to carry out a biochemical reaction, they in most cases need energy.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of bond is formed between orthophosphoric acid residues in ATP molecules?
reference-answers: A lot of energy is required to form this bond, but during its destruction, energy is released in large quantities.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: How does the formation of di- or triorthophosphates from monoorthophosphate nucleotides relate to energy storage?
reference-answers: To do this, one or two orthophosphoric acid residues are added to nucleotides of monoorthophosphates (for example, AMP) and a molecule of di- or triorthophosphates (respectively, ADP or ATP) is formed.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of bond holds a disulfide bond together?
reference-answers: A disulfide bond can occur between different parts of the same polypeptide chain, then it keeps this chain in a bent state.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What types of bonds are present in protein molecules?
reference-answers: Protein molecules contain covalent bonds (peptide and disulfide bonds) and noncovalent bonds (hydrogen, ionic bonds, and hydrophobic interactions).

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: What type of bond occurs between Hydrogen atoms with a partially positive charge and an atom with a partially negative charge?
reference-answers: Occurs between Hydrogen atoms, which have a partially positive charge, of one functional group and an atom (Oxygen, Nitrogen), which has a partially negative charge and an unshared electron pair, of another functional group.

ukr-biology/book03/topic01- /text.en..question: Where does the disulfide bond occur in a protein molecule?
reference-answers: If a disulfide bond occurs between two polypeptides, then it unites them into one molecule.

ukr-biology/book03/topic04- /text.en.t.question: What are genes?
reference-answers: Each gene is a section of a DNA molecule. It is responsible for the formation of one or more traits of an organism.

ukr-biology/book03/topic05- /text.en.tx.question: What is the difference between hereditary and non-hereditary variability?

ukr-biology/book03/topic05- /text.en.tx.question: What are the mechanisms of combinatorial variation in prokaryotes?

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: When did Homo sapiens first reach the Americas?
reference-answers: Exactly when this occurred is not clear, but it likely started around eighteen thousand years ago at the earliest.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was Beringia before it was consumed by rising waters?
reference-answers: Beringia has since been consumed by rising waters and now lies under the Bering Strait.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the likely time period when Homo sapiens reached the Americas?
reference-answers: About eighteen thousand years ago, the last glaciation period was entering its peak stage, and sea levels globally were far lower than they are today.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What is believed to be a possible route of migration down the west coast?
reference-answers: It is very likely, for example, that some populations moved down the west coast via a combination of land travel and coastal skirting by raft or canoe.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: Why did the Clovis culture eventually vanish?
reference-answers: The Clovis culture that spread across North America around thirteen thousand years ago vanished after only a few centuries.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was a major resource for the hunter-gatherer societies that settled along the Pacific Northwest?
reference-answers: They likely migrated into the area by following caribou, which they hunted. Once they settled in the densely forested region, they learned to survive on beaver, elk, seals, birds, sea lions, and salmon and a great many other fish species.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was one of the ways that wealth contributed to social differentiation in these societies?
reference-answers: In the burial sites of the very wealthy, for example, archaeologists have found carved tools made of antler and other objects made from shells.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What type of climate made the bison able to adapt?
reference-answers: Unlike the animals hunted by the Clovis people, the bison were able to adapt to the warming climate conditions and flourished in the plains.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What is a strategy used by hunters in the Great Plains region?
reference-answers: We know from archaeological sites in central Canada, Texas, Montana, Wyoming, and Colorado that as long ago as 8000 BCE, hunters used a strategy of driving herds of bison over cliffs to their death.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What type of environment existed south of Mesoamerica?
reference-answers: The environment is warmer, greener, and wetter. The formerly largegame-hunting peoples settled there after around 8000 BCE as the game disappeared and the bison followed the retreating grassland north.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: When did the gathering of wild plants wane considerably?
reference-answers: By around 5000 BCE, the settlers earlier reliance on wild game had given way to a more plant-based diet that included beans, squash, maize (corn), and bottle gourds. By 2600 BCE, the gathering of wild plants had waned considerably as groups adopted agricultural practices, cultivating maize, beans, and squash.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: At what altitude was Guitarrero Cave located?
reference-answers: One such site is Guitarrero Cave, located at an altitude of 8,500 feet near the small town of Mancos in central Peru.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: How far away was the obsidian found at Quebrada Jaguay?
reference-answers: Obsidian found at the site, originating about one hundred miles away, is even more surprising; it suggests that long-distance trade may have been occurring in the region many thousands of years ago.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: When did the Neolithic Revolution in the Americas occur?
reference-answers: For this reason, technological and cultural developments in Asia, Africa, and Europe were not disseminated to the Americas for many thousands of years.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: When did domestication of squash and bottle gourds begin?
reference-answers: Some discoveries place the earliest cultivation of squash and bottle gourds at around 8000 BCE.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the approximate date range for domestication of camelids in the Andean region?
reference-answers: In some parts of the region, the domestication of camelids such as llamas, guanacos, and alpacas for meat and later wool may have begun as early as 7400 BCE.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What is the Norte Chico civilization also known as?
reference-answers: The similarities among sites in central coastal Peru have led archaeologists to describe them as belonging to one larger culture, sometimes called the Norte Chico or the Caral civilization.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: How did maize become an important staple carbohydrate in Mesoamerica?
reference-answers: While debate continues about how exactly that process occurred, it is generally accepted that human intervention transformed the thick wild grass into the large, sturdy, cob-producing plants we know today.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What type of social organization is likely to have existed in the Norte Chico civilization?
reference-answers: Based on an examination of the burial sites and the likely ritual significance of many of the ruins, there appear to have been social divisions and organized spiritual or religious practice.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was a likely ruling system in the Norte Chico civilization?
reference-answers: Given the large-scale architecture and the need for laborers, it is also almost certain there was some type of powerful hereditary leadership.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: Why were the agricultural traditions developed in South America not easily disseminated north into Mesoamerica?
reference-answers: Given the great distance and climate differences between the Andean region and Mesoamerica, the agricultural traditions developed in South America were not easily disseminated north into Mesoamerica in Neolithic times.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: How was maize domesticated?
reference-answers: Maize was domesticated from a type of wild edible grass known as teosinte between 5000 and 3000 BCE.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: When did maize emergence in the Andean region begin?
reference-answers: Evidence for Mesoamerican maize in the Andean region dates to about 1600 BCE.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: How was sunflower domesticated?
reference-answers: The domestication of sunflowers, useful for their oily and nutritious seeds, appears to have begun by about 2300 BCE.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What led to the decline of gathering activities in Mesoamerica?
reference-answers: The labor demands of doing so and the caloric value of maize led to a steady decline of gathering activities, resulting in exclusively sedentary agricultural communities.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: When did groups in the Eastern Woodlands begin making concerted efforts to increase their food supply by altering the physical environment?
reference-answers: However, by about 2000 BCE, groups in this region began making concerted efforts to increase their food supply by altering the physical environment, clearing small plots of land to more carefully cultivate these wild plants.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was a notable change that occurred among Eastern Woodlands peoples due to the increasing availability of food and exposure to wealth in the form of traded materials?
reference-answers: The increasing availability of food and exposure to wealth in the form of traded materials led to social transformations like a reduction in the egalitarianism common among hunter-gatherers.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What type of site was constructed at Poverty Point, located in northern Louisiana?
reference-answers: There, beginning around 1000 BCE, several U-shaped concentric mounds were constructed to form an impressive and unusual ceremonial site.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the approximate number of members in most Eastern Woodlands groups?
reference-answers: Groups in the Eastern Woodlands remained small, likely no more than one hundred or so members in most places.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What type of materials could pass from one small group to another and move many hundreds of miles?
reference-answers: Certain types of stone, copper materials, and shells from the coastlines could pass from one small group to another and in the process move many hundreds of miles.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: When did groups at Poverty Point begin constructing ceremonial sites?
reference-answers: Beginning around 1000 BCE, several U-shaped concentric mounds were constructed to form an impressive and unusual ceremonial site.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the approximate duration for which Poverty Point was an active site?
reference-answers: It was an active site for about three hundred years before being abandoned for reasons unknown.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: When did the peoples living in the Americas begin to form complex agricultural-based societies?
reference-answers: At the start of the third century BCE, after thousands of years of hunter-gatherer existence, the peoples living in the Americas began to form complex agricultural-based societies.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the approximate weight of some of the massive stone sculptures carved by the Olmec civilization?
reference-answers: The massive stone heads and other sculptures, some weighing as much as fifty tons, were carved from volcanic basalt that came from as far as ninety miles away.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the likely purpose of the 'red palace' structure built by the Olmec civilization?

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: Other rituals were connected to a type of ball game played in a special court with balls made from the abundant natural rubber of the region.
reference-answers: Sports contests often existed to bring communities together, to allow men to show prowess and strength in times of peace, and to entertain. It is also likely that in times of heightened spiritual need, such contests could take on greater meaning and might have been choreographed to play out supernatural narratives and perhaps connect people to the gods.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: Some scholars thus conclude that Olmec civilization was a mother culture for later large and sophisticated Mesoamerican states.
reference-answers: Over time, this trade exposed other Mesoamerican cultures to Olmec ideas about religion, art, architecture, and governance. Some scholars thus conclude that Olmec civilization was a mother culture for later large and sophisticated Mesoamerican states.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What type of region did the Zapotec civilization develop in?

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: Why do historians believe Monte Albn was likely selected as a settlement site?

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What type of trade did Teotihuacan dominate across southern Mexico?

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What type of structure was the Citadel in the Teotihuacan site?
reference-answers: The site also includes a large royal residence known as the Citadel, which includes the elaborate Temple of Quetzalcoatl, the feathered serpent.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: Where did the Teotihuacanos build their largest temples?
reference-answers: The largest temples are known as the Pyramid of the Sun and the Pyramid of the Moon. Both are multitiered stone structures, 197 and 141 feet tall, respectively.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was a common feature among the major cities of the Early Classic period Maya civilization?
reference-answers: Most of the major cities were built next to large, shallow lakes, since access to water for drinking and irrigation was important in the lowlands, where rainfall was often insufficient.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What event is believed to have occurred in the powerful Maya city of Tikal in 378 CE?
reference-answers: They may even have orchestrated a coup in the powerful Maya city of Tikal in 378.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was one way the Teotihuacanos exerted their influence over other civilizations?
reference-answers: To influence areas so far away, the city wielded power through its control of trade and use of military force and diplomacy.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What type of agriculture did the Maya develop due to insufficient tropical soil?
reference-answers: The tropical soil in the area is also insufficiently fertile, and the Maya developed a style of slash-and-burn agriculture to raise maize, squash, beans, and cacao for the growing urban populations in these cities.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: Why did rulers rarely control conquered city-states?
reference-answers: Only rarely did rulers seek to control conquered city-states, however.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the purpose of ritual ball game in Maya mythology?
reference-answers: The intention was to reenact aspects of Maya mythology, and the game held a significant place in religious practice.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What caused the decline of the Classical Maya civilization?
reference-answers: The reason for this collapse has been a topic of debate among historians and archaeologists for many years, and much remains uncertain. Among the proposed causes are epidemic diseases, invasions, natural disasters, internal revolutions, and environmental degradation.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the likely reason for the growth in population of the Mayan civilization?
reference-answers: This growth led to large-scale deforestation, which in turn produced soil erosion. Large populations that required high agricultural yields made Mayan civilization more vulnerable to variations in climate or a string of bad harvests caused by crop disease.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the significance of the transformation in the Andes region around 900 BCE?
reference-answers: Around 900 BCE, the Andes region experienced a transformation when a single society, often called the Chavn culture, expanded across the entire area, opening what archaeologists call the Early Horizon, or Formative, period.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the likely impact of large-scale deforestation on Mayan civilization?
reference-answers: This growth led to large-scale deforestation, which in turn produced soil erosion. Large populations that required high agricultural yields made Mayan civilization more vulnerable to variations in climate or a string of bad harvests caused by crop disease.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: How did the collapse of the Classical Maya civilization affect the overall region?
reference-answers: Over a period of about a century, alliances broke down, conflicts became more common, the production of luxury goods slowed to a stop, and cities went from thriving urban centers to depopulated shells.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What is the name of the culture known for its distinctive pottery style?
reference-answers: The Chavn culture is known for its distinctive pottery style, which spread throughout the entire region and depicted numerous people, deities, and animals in a flowing and balanced manner ( Figure 8.19 ).

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What is the name of the deity sculpture found at Chavn de Huntar?
reference-answers: Deep within the tunnels was a large sculpture of possibly this cultures chief deity, called El Lanzn (great lance) because of its long lance-like shape.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: How many inhabitants did Chavn de Huntar have by 200 BCE?
reference-answers: The inhabitants of Chavn de Huntar numbered about twenty-five hundred by 200 BCE as it slipped into decline.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What is the approximate time period when the influence of Chavn cultural styles and religious symbols began to wane?
reference-answers: Beginning around 200 BCE, the influence of Chavn cultural styles and religious symbols began to wane.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was a major factor that contributed to the decline of Chavn culture?
reference-answers: Beginning around 200 BCE, the influence of Chavn cultural styles and religious symbols began to wane. This came at a time of increased regional warfare among many groups, evidenced by the increasing use of defensive features like walls around settlements.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the role of Chavn de Huntar in its society?
reference-answers: The sites importance lay in its role as a religious or ceremonial site, not as a population center.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the result of Chavn cultural styles and symbols spreading across the region?
reference-answers: The broader Chavn-influenced region then fragmented into a number of regional cultures that grew to full-fledged civilizations like the Moche, Nazca, and Tiwanaku ( Figure 8.21 ).

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the purpose of the large sunken court in the Highlands area around Lake Titicaca?
reference-answers: The construction of a large sunken court in this area around 1000 BCE indicates they had their own sophisticated ceremonial rituals.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: How did the Chavn culture influence other societies in the region?
reference-answers: Innovations in textile production and metalworking in gold, silver, and copper also proliferated around the region.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the role of llamas as pack animals in the spread of Chavn cultural styles?
reference-answers: Craftspeople in towns and villages produced textiles and metal objects, and traders moved them from place to place along improved routes and with the aid of llamas as pack animals ( Figure 8.20 ).

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was the approximate height of Chavn de Huntar?
reference-answers: This site is more than ten thousand feet high in the Andes Mountains, to the east of the older Norte Chico settlements.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: When did the influence of Chavn cultural styles and religious symbols begin to wane?
reference-answers: Beginning around 200 BCE, the influence of Chavn cultural styles and religious symbols began to wane.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What is notable about the Nazca Lines?
reference-answers: Some are as large as twelve hundred feet long and were created by clearing stones away from the desert floor to reveal the different-colored ground beneath.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was unique about the Moche civilization's cities?
reference-answers: Their cities and burial practices reflect a hierarchical organization, with powerful divine kings and families of nobles ruling from atop large pyramids.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: Why did the Nazca people live in small villages?
reference-answers: Unlike the Moche in their large cities, the Nazca people lived mostly in small villages.

world-history/chapter08-The-Americas-in-.question: What was notable about the Tiwanaku civilization's building period?
reference-answers: Beginning around 100 CE, it entered a period of sustained building at its key city of Tiwanaku.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Why was the development of written scripts less common among the peoples of the Inner Asian Steppe?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What were some of the consequences of the Xiongnu's interactions with China?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the impact of the Silk Roads on the struggle between the Xiongnu and the Chinese?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Why did some groups of Xiongnu become vassals of the Chinese?
reference-answers: Less powerful groups in these wars tended to move toward the frontier of the Chinese empire and try to secure Chinese support against their rivals.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What were the main activities of the Xiongnu tribes after they moved west?
reference-answers: Hundreds of thousands of Xiongnu lived inside the borders of Chinas empire, often becoming more settled and assimilated in their lifestyles and cultural practices.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was a significant consequence of adopting Chinese customs among the Xianbei?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was a result of the opulence and culture of the Northern Wei court?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was a significant outcome of the civil war and sack of Luoyang?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What event led to years of civil war in China?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What is unique about the cultural exchanges between ancient Korea and Japan?
reference-answers: Via trade, religion, and diplomacy, Korea and Japan borrowed and adapted from Chinese civilization, but even more importantly from each other.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: How did Buddhist missionaries adapt to different cultures in Southeast Asia?
reference-answers: But in each destination the faith was transformed into hundreds of new sects and interpretations of the path to enlightenment.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Why is Korea's landform unique compared to its neighboring regions?
reference-answers: The earliest humans to reach the Korean peninsula did so around thirty thousand years ago. The land is very hilly, and mountains in the north form a barrier with Manchuria.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was unique about bronze production in ancient Korea?
reference-answers: Archaeologists have found evidence of bronze weapons dating back to 1300 BCE, but no clear proof that Korea at that time produced a Bronze Age civilization.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: When did humans first reach the Korean peninsula?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Who awarded a fief known as Joseon in northern Korea to a Chinese noble referred to as Gija?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What culture did Korean tribal societies mimic when they were unable to trade?
reference-answers: When unable to trade, Korean tribal societies mimicked the Xiongnu and raided the Chinese settlements, drawing strength and forging their own war bands.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Who struggled to defend themselves against rising powers in the north in the fourth and fifth centuries CE?
reference-answers: In the fourth and fifth centuries CE, all three struggled to defend themselves against rising powers in the north, such as the Xianbei.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What were the Three Han societies known collectively?
reference-answers: Chinese sources from the time refer to people in the southwest as the Mahan, those in the southeast as Jinhan, and between them a group known as the Byeonhan.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the process called when a young male married his elder brother's widow?
reference-answers: Practices such as the levirate, in which a young male marries his elder brothers widow, were used widely by Inner Asian Steppe peoples and adopted by a number of early Korean ruling families.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Why did the Three Han societies lack horses?
reference-answers: The Three Han were far less formidable military powers than their counterparts to the north, in part because they lacked horses and fought primarily on foot.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the name of the age known for speeding up the process of state-building in Korea?
reference-answers: The decline of Chinese power in the fourth century unleashed a wave of refugees that proved pivotal in speeding up the process of state-building in Korea, opening an age known as the Three Kingdoms (313668 CE).

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What were the three kingdoms that existed during the age known as the Three Kingdoms in Korea?
reference-answers: The three kingdoms in questions were Goguryeo, Baekje, and Silla (Figure 5.11).

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was a critical skill for those excluded from the ranks of aristocratic families during the Three Kingdoms era?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was one of the critical developments in Goguryeo's expansion that marked its power?
reference-answers: The first was its skillful use of diplomacy and regional politics to manage alliances and threats, playing off groups within and around the Korean peninsula to secure its power.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was one of the developments in Goguryeo's expansion that marked its adoption from China?
reference-answers: The second was the adoption of a written script from China, evidenced by 414 CE in a stone slab inscribed to note the accomplishments of King Gwanggaeto upon his death.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: How did Buddhism develop and grow into distinct sects and traditions in Korea?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was a key sign of nobility and refinement in Korean royalty during the Three Kingdoms era?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was one of the famous Buddhist monuments built during the Three Kingdoms era?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What groups traveled as far as India and central Asia to bring back knowledge and expertise?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the outcome of Queen Seondeok's diplomacy with the Tang dynasty?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What event marked the end of unified rule over much of the peninsula?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What motivated Baekje's rulers to create a Chinese-style bureaucracy?
reference-answers: To consolidate their control over the southwestern area of the peninsula, Baekjes rulers created a Chinese-style bureaucracy with a chief minister and carried on a successful maritime trade with China and Japan.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What event led to Silla's alliance with a reunified China under the Sui and then the Tang dynasties?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the result of Silla's collaboration with the defeated forces of its rivals?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was unique about Queen Seondeok's reign?
reference-answers: Part of Queen Seondeoks legacy was a period of unprecedented female rule, during which new art forms emerged that in later centuries became distinctive Korean traditions.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What is the Ring of Fire?
reference-answers: Critical to the formation of the main islands and their geographical features is the belt known as the Ring of Fire ( Figure 5.15 ), mapped by a horseshoe-shaped line drawn around the rim of the Pacific Ocean to mark a zone of frequent earthquake and volcanic activity that has generated countless tsunamis in Japans distant past and modern day.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: When did the climate shift that severed Japan from the Asian continent around?
reference-answers: The climate shift that severed Japan from the Asian continent around twelve thousand years ago transformed the newly formed isles and the game these people once hunted.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What technology did the early inhabitants of Japan invent to enhance their chances for survival?
reference-answers: In the caves of Kyushu, archaeologists have found evidence of one of the worlds earliest technological breakthroughs, the development of pottery.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was likely the purpose of using Jmon pottery?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was a characteristic of the increasingly sophisticated culture of the Jmon people?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was a significant threat to the Jmon people's food supply?
reference-answers: Skeletal remains of the Jmon people suggest that despite their diverse diet of fruits, nuts, and seafood such as clams and fish, they lived with the constant threat of starvation and malnutrition.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: How did the Yayoi culture impact Japan's prehistory?
reference-answers: The Yayoi period marked a turning point in Japans prehistory. From this point forward, Korea, China, and Japan were in more consistent contact than in the centuries before.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the effect of agriculture on the Yayoi population?
reference-answers: Agriculture brought stability and growth, and the Yayoi population is estimated to have ballooned to more than half a million people by the first centuries of the common era.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the main factor that led to the emergence of states in Japan during the Yayoi period?
reference-answers: Over time, the appeal of certain areas and sites for agriculture led to competition and increasing warfare and, by extension, the emergence of states to provide for defense.

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Who was recognized as an ally by the Chinese emperor in return for paying tribute, and what was she given?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What practice did ancient Japanese women exercise political power and influence through?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Why was sailing a universally efficient craft for merchants and adventurers in Southeast Asia?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: How did Southeast Asian societies adapt and preserve their indigenous customs in response to foreign influences?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Who were the peoples dominating Southeast Asia's coastline settlements before Indian contact?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the name of the cultural sphere emanating from the east that influenced the area near today's Vietnam?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the name of the bronze drum-making culture in northern Vietnam that produced drums decorated with cords and images of animals?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What were the three distinct zones that shaped the evolution of Vietnam from ancient times to the present?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: When did chiefdoms grow increasingly large in Vietnam?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the main goal of the Han dynasty's governance in northern Vietnam?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was unique about the status of women in Champa civilization?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the main trade network that existed in Champa?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the significance of Shiva in Champa kings?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the significance of the Dong Son culture in Champa?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was the name of the region to the south of Champa that was mentioned by Chinese texts?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: Why did the Indus valley civilization decline?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What was a primary function of writing in the Indus Valley Civilization?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What type of art was influenced by the Indus Valley Civilization?

world-history/chapter05-Asia-in-Ancient-.question: What is the reason for the prohibition against marrying Indians from another caste?
