reference-answers: Sometime in the 1000s, the dynasty Islamized, possibly under Za Kusay, whom the History of the Sudan remembers as the first Muslim ruler of Songhai.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What is the name given to the earliest dynasty of kings of the Songhai state?
reference-answers: The Za are an obscure dynasty; what evidence exists comes to us in the form of myths and legends, the seventeenth-century History of the Sudan, the oral tradition of the Songhai written down by Abd al-Sadi, and some tombstone inscriptions dating to the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: When did the Islamization of the Songhai rulers occur?
reference-answers: Modern scholars believe the Islamization of the Songhai rulers occurred toward the end of the eleventh century with the arrival of the Sanhaja Almoravids from Morocco.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: Who became the first king of the Songhai Empire?
reference-answers: The leader of the Songhai rebels, Sunni Ali, became the first king of the Songhai Empire.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What led to the criticism of Sunni Ali by Arabic historians?
reference-answers: Despite being Muslim himself, Sunni Ali campaigned against Muslim forces. This and his general lack of respect for Islam led to his being highly criticized by Arabic historians.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What event occurred around 1325 that impacted the prosperity of Gao?
reference-answers: Gaos prosperity also drew the attention of the new and expansionist West African kingdom of Mali, which annexed Gao around 1325.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: Why did Sunni Ali's scholars in Timbuktu flee to Oualata?
reference-answers: As a result, many of the scholars in Timbuktu fled to Oualata, leading to a significant diminishment in Islamic scholarship in the city

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What motivated many Africans to revolt against Islamic rule?
reference-answers: They insisted that cruel rulers be removed from power and replaced by pious men.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: Why were Islamized Africans treated as second-class Muslims in conquered provinces?
reference-answers: Heavily taxed subjects in conquered provinces whose daughters were sometimes enslaved, the Islamized Africans were treated as second-class Muslims.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the outcome of these revolts that erupted across North Africa in 739 and 740?
reference-answers: Widespread opposition took the form of revolts that erupted across North Africa in 739 and 740 and shattered the Islamic Caliphate.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: Why did it take nearly two hundred years for North Africa to unite under Muslim rulers again?
reference-answers: It took nearly two hundred years for North Africa to unite under Muslim rulers again.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: Who were the rulers known as the Fatimids?
reference-answers: These rulers were known as the Fatimids, Shia Muslims who did not recognize the authority of the Abbasids who had succeeded the Umayyads in 750.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: Why did the Fatimid missionaries convert the Kutama in Algeria?
reference-answers: Fatimid missionaries had long been active in Iraq and Syria before converting the Kutama in Algeria.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the ultimate goal of the Fatimid Caliphate?
reference-answers: The Fatimids established a Shiite caliphate in Cairo, but their ultimate goal was to conquer the Sunni Abbasid Caliphate in Baghdad and establish a caliphate that was the center of the Muslim world.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was unique about the military strategy of the Fatimids?
reference-answers: Taking a page from the Abbasids, the Fatimids diversified their army, enlisting free and enslaved Turks alongside indigenous African soldiers and transforming their tribal force into a multiethnic one.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the result of the Fatimid caliph's attempt to reassert Shia Muslim control?
reference-answers: The Fatimid caliph attempted to reassert Shia Muslim control by encouraging tens of thousands of Arabs to migrate westward, pressuring the frontiers of the breakaway Ziridi state and causing war.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the outcome of Ibn Yasin's efforts among the Djuddala tribe?
reference-answers: Anyone who fell short of Ibn Yasins strict demands for discipline and the observation of religious duties was severely punished.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What happened to the Almoravids after Ibn Yasin's expulsion?
reference-answers: Under Ibn Yasins direction the Almoravids became zealous reformers committed to imposing his version of Islam on the people of the Maghreb.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the outcome of the Almoravids' campaign against other tribes?
reference-answers: In 1052, Ibn Yasin and the Almoravids embarked on a years-long campaign to defeat the other tribes of the region, assembling an impressive army in the process.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the outcome of Saladin's pledge allegiance to the Abbasids?
reference-answers: When Saladin pledged allegiance to the Abbasids a few years later, this brought Egypt back into the Sunni-dominated Islamic Caliphate.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: Who led the Almoravids?
reference-answers: Ibn Yasin himself was expelled. While in exile, he received a steady stream of followers from both the Lamtuna and Djuddala Sanhaja, forming a group he soon came to call the Almoravids.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the name of Ibn Tumart's movement?
reference-answers: A reformer, he sought a return to what he believed was the original, uncorrupted Islamic.faith and rejected all of the schools of Islamic law because he considered their pronouncements to be heretical interpretations of the teachings of the prophet Muhammad.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the name given to Ibn Tumart's followers?
reference-answers: Ibn Tumarts followers adopted the name Almohads, meaning those of the oneness, a reference to their belief in the transcendental unity of God.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the Almohad Empire's control over Spain like?
reference-answers: At the end of the century, the Almohad Empire extended across all of Muslim Spain (Figure 15.20).

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: Why did the Christian forces capture all of Spain north of Granada?
reference-answers: By the middle of the thirteenth century, Christian forces had captured all of Spain north of Granada (which fell in 1492).

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What happened to Marrakesh in 1275?
reference-answers: Meanwhile, insurgencies in the Maghreb and the sacking of Marrakesh by rebels in 1275 brought the Almohad Empire to an end.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What was the relationship between the Almoravids and the Masmuda tribes?
reference-answers: It was among these nomads that Ibn Tumart began to recruit the Masmuda tribes into a force to oppose the Almoravids.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What ideology did Ibn Tumart promote?
reference-answers: Like the Sanhaja before them, the Masmuda dominated both the administration and the military of Almohad Spain. The manuals of Malikite legal doctrine were banned and later burned, to be replaced by the teachings of Ibn Tumart, who died in 1130.

world-history/chapter15-States-and-Socie.question: What happened to the Almohad Empire's dominance?
reference-answers: Almohad dominance turned out to be short-lived, however. No sooner did it reach its peak around 1200 than the empire of the Masmuda started to crumble, due in part to pressures from Christians to the north.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What kind of society did the civilization that produced the wooden box in Ur have?
reference-answers: This kind of specialized craftsmanship was a hallmark of societies that no longer depended on hunting and gathering for food but rather produced crops capable of sustaining large populations.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What does the mosaics in the wooden box indicate about social hierarchy?
reference-answers: These power dynamics suggest new social hierarchies. Finally, the soldiers all appear smaller in the scene than the king, symbolically reflecting their subordinate position and telling us that social stratification had come into existence.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: When did the development of early civilizations occur?
reference-answers: The development of early civilizations occurred between 10,000 and 8,000 BCE in just a few specific areas of the world that historians have labeled the cradles of civilization.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was a key feature of early civilizations?
reference-answers: This system of specialization was a key feature of early civilizations and what distinguished them from previous societies. Individuals performed specific tasks such as farming, writing, or performing religious rituals.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the primary cause of population growth?
reference-answers: Population growth rooted in agricultural production led to larger cities, in which the food produced by farmers in outlying rural areas was distributed among the population of the urban center, where food was not produced.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: How did the system of specialization affect social hierarchy?
reference-answers: Those who could accumulate more goods became wealthy, and they passed that wealth from one generation to the next. This wealth led, in turn, to the accumulation of political and religious power, while those who continued to labor in production remained lower on the social scale.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the region where wheat was first domesticated around 10,000 BCE?
reference-answers: This region is commonly called the Fertile Crescent (because of its shape). It includes Mesopotamia (modern Iraq), southern Anatolia (modern Turkey), and the Levant (modern Syria, Lebanon, Israel, and Palestine) and has yielded the earliest evidence of agriculture.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the significance of bull sacrifices in Neolithic settlements?
reference-answers: An agricultural surplus enabled religious specialists to devote time to performing bull sacrifices at atalhyk, for example, and freed artisans to hone their skills to create the frescoes that decorated the interior space where these sacrifices occurred.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: At what time period did Neolithic settlements appear in modern Pakistan?
reference-answers: As early as 7000 BCE, a Neolithic settlement appeared in modern Pakistan, at a site today known as Mehrgarh, whose inhabitants engaged in long-distance trade, grew barley, and raised goats and sheep.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is the term Mesopotamia likely derived from?
reference-answers: The term Mesopotamia, or the land between the rivers in Greek, likely originated with the Greek historian Herodotus in the fifth century BCE and has become the common name for the place between the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers in what is now Iraq.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Where did the common name for the place between the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers likely originate?
reference-answers: , likely originated with the Greek historian Herodotus in the fifth century BCE and has become the common name for the place between the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers in what is now Iraq.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was a significant technological innovation developed by the Sumerians around 4000 BCE?
reference-answers: One important invention made after 4000 BCE was the process for manufacturing bronze, an alloy of tin and copper, which marked the beginning of the Bronze Age in Mesopotamia.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: How many large cities were mentioned in the text as existing during the fourth millennium BCE?
reference-answers: By the end of the millennium, there were at least 124 villages with about one hundred residents each, twenty towns with as many as two thousand residents, another twenty small urban centers of about five thousand residents, and one large city, Uruk, with a population that may have been as high as fifty thousand.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the name of the script developed by the Sumerians?
reference-answers: The ancient Sumerians also developed the plow, the wheel, and irrigation techniques that used small channels and canals with dikes for diverting river water into fields. All these developments allowed for population growth and the continued rise of cities by expanding agricultural production and the distribution of agricultural goods. In the area of science, the Sumerians developed a sophisticated mathematical system based on the numbers sixty, ten, and one.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was cuneiform?
reference-answers: a script characterized by wedge-shaped symbols that evolved into a phonetic script, that is, one based on sounds, in which each symbol stood for a syllable

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why did the Sumerians use clay tablets?
reference-answers: which became very durable once baked, just like the clay bricks the Sumerians used to construct their buildings

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the significance of ziggurats in Sumerian society?
reference-answers: a site where the deity was worshipped and religious rituals were performed

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What were the primary ways in which common people praised their gods?
reference-answers: For common people, it meant living a virtuous life and giving to the poor.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Who was the most famous lugal in all Sumer during this period?
reference-answers: The most famous lugal in all Sumer in this early period was Gilgamesh of Uruk, whose legendary exploits were recounted later in fantastical form in the Epic of Gilgamesh.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What event marked the end of the era of independent Sumerian city-states?
reference-answers: The Rise of the Worlds First Empire Around 2300 BCE, the era of the independent Sumerian city-state , a political entity consisting of a city and surrounding territory that it controls, came to an end.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the Akkadian Empire created by Sargon?
reference-answers: The Akkadian Empire that Sargon created lasted for about a century and a half, officially coming to an end in the year 2193 BCE.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the main rival of Yahweh among the ancient Israelites?
reference-answers: Other rivals of the Akkadians were the Elamites, who inhabited the region to the immediate southeast of Mesopotamia in southwest Iran and whose city of Susa arose around 4000 BCE.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why would Sargon's rise to power have been a powerful piece of propaganda?
reference-answers: This interesting tale would have certainly been a powerful piece of propaganda justifying Sargons rule and endearing him to the common people,

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the significance of the Legend of Sargon?
reference-answers: The story Sargon told about himself, at least, has likely been accurately preserved in the Legend of Sargon, written two centuries after his death as a purported autobiography.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the writing system developed by the Elamites?
reference-answers: They developed their own writing system around 3000 BCE, even though they adapted Sumerian cuneiform to their language later in the third millennium BCE.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Who originally inhabited the region to the immediate southeast of Mesopotamia?
reference-answers: ls of the Akkadians were the Elamites, who inhabited the region to the immediate southeast of Mesopotamia in southwest Iran and whose city of Susa arose around 4000 BCE.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the title held by the rulers of the Third Dynasty of Ur?
reference-answers: The rulers of this dynasty held the title of lugal of all Sumer and Akkad, and they were also honored as gods.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the name of the most famous lugal of the Third Dynasty of Ur?
reference-answers: The most famous lugal of this dynasty was Ur-Nammu (c. 2150 BCE), renowned for his works of poetry as well as for the law code he published.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the approximate year in which the Akkadian Empire collapsed?
reference-answers: In the year 2193 BCE, however, the Akkadian Empire collapsed.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the approximate year when Sumer crumbled?
reference-answers: By about 2004 BCE, Sumer had crumbled, and even Ur was violently sacked by the invaders.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: How long did Hammurabi's empire last?
reference-answers: Hammurabis empire lasted a century and a half.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What happened to Babylon's territory after Hammurabi's death?
reference-answers: much of the territory he conquered began falling away from Babylons control shortly after he died.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: When did the Kassites conquer Babylon and southern Mesopotamia?
reference-answers: Shortly thereafter, Kassites from the Zagros Mountains of northwestern Iran conquered Babylon and southern Mesopotamia and settled there...

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What event led to the decline of Sumerian as a spoken language?
reference-answers: the migration of Amorites into Mesopotamia resulted in the gradual disappearance of Sumerian as a spoken language.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What happened to Babylon after its capture by Hittites?
reference-answers: The empire continued to dwindle in size until 1595 BCE, when an army of Hittites from central Anatolia in the north (modern Turkey) sacked the city of Babylon.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the main difference between the culture adopted by Kassite rulers and that of their Mesopotamian subjects?
reference-answers: Like the Guti and the Amorites before them, over time, the Kassite rulers adopted the culture of their Mesopotamian subjects.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What percentage of the population in southern Mesopotamia lived in cities?
reference-answers: About 70 to 80 percent of the population lived in cities, but not all were employed as artisans, merchants, or other traditional urban roles.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Who typically performed hard labor in the fields?
reference-answers: Much of the hard labor performed in the fields was done by men and boys, while the wives, mothers, and daughters of merchants and artisans were sometimes fully engaged in running family businesses.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What percentage of the population made up free peasants?
reference-answers: For example, cuneiform tablets from circa 1900 BCE show that merchants from Ashur in northern Mesopotamia conducted trade with central Anatolia and wrote letters to their female family members back home. Women were also engaged in the production of textiles like wool and linen.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was a common punishment for harming or murdering an aristocrat?
reference-answers: This principle is best summarized in the line an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth. However, the principle applied only to victims and perpetrators of the same social class.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was required for a woman to divorce her husband?
reference-answers: A man was free to have multiple wives and divorce a wife at will, whereas a woman could divorce her husband only if she could prove he had been unkind to her without reason.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the social distinction in Mesopotamian law regarding punishment for physical harm?
reference-answers: Aspects of Hammurabis law code called for punishments for causing physical harm to another to be equal to the harm inflicted.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the social distinction in Mesopotamian law regarding marriage and divorce?
reference-answers: However, a woman from a family of means could protect her position in a marriage if her family put up a dowry, which could be land or goods.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the percentage of the population that made up the elite nobility?
reference-answers: This aristocratic elite often received land in payment for their services to the kings and collected rents in kind from their peasant tenants.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was a common occupation of women in Mesopotamia?
reference-answers: Women were also engaged in the production of textiles like wool and linen.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the outcome if a husband divorced or was unkind to his wife?
reference-answers: Upon marriage, the husband obtained the dowry, but if he divorced or was unkind to his wife, he had to return it to her and her family.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why do historians believe Mesopotamians had a generally pessimistic worldview?
reference-answers: The ancient Mesopotamians belief that the gods were fickle, destructive, and easily stirred to anger is one reason many historians believe they had a generally pessimistic worldview.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the environment like in which Mesopotamian civilization emerged?
reference-answers: Given the environment in which Mesopotamian civilization emerged, this pessimism is somewhat understandable.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What were common environmental issues for Mesopotamian civilization?
reference-answers: River flooding was common and could often be unpredictable and destructive.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why did the environment of Egypt's Nile River valley make it a unique civilization?
reference-answers: The region was highly hospitable to the many Paleolithic peoples living there and surviving on its abundant resources.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What happened to the environment of Egypt's Nile River valley around 6000 BCE?
reference-answers: As the environment became more difficult for humans to survive in, they retreated to oases and rivers on the fringes.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the main reason for the shift in human settlement as the Sahara transformed into the Sahara we recognize today?
reference-answers: an to give way to sand as the once green environment was transformed into the Sahara we recognize today.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What significant event occurred in about 3150 BCE, leading to a major political and cultural shift in Egypt?
reference-answers: A major political and cultural shift occurred in about 3150 BCE when Upper and Lower Egypt were unified into a single powerful kingdom.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why was ancient Egypt protected from invasion, unlike Mesopotamia?
reference-answers: On both east and west, the Nile River valley was surrounded by large deserts that were difficult to cross.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is the term for the king of ancient Egypt?
reference-answers: The Pharaoh The king of the united Egypt, the pharaoh, governed a kingdom much larger than any contemporary realm.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why was the pharaoh considered to be a god?
reference-answers: As a deity, the pharaoh was the human form or incarnation of Horus, the god of justice and truth.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What were the three main gods worshipped by the Ancient Egyptians?
reference-answers: Ancient Egyptians were polytheists and worshipped many deities who controlled the forces of nature. For example, Re was the god of the sun, and Isis was the earth goddess of fertility.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the central event of the Egyptian year?
reference-answers: The annual flooding of the river, the central event of the Egyptian year, was explained through the myth of Osiris, who was murdered by his brother Seth, the god of the desert wind, but then resurrected by his devoted wife Isis.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is the significance of the Nile's flooding in Egyptian religion?
reference-answers: the Nile played an important role in the development of Egyptian religion.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why did Egyptians develop their own unique writing system?
reference-answers: Egyptians developed their own unique writing system, known today by the Greek word hieroglyphics (meaning sacred writings),

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the concept of Ma'at in Egyptian religion?
reference-answers: In later centuries, this notion developed into the concept of Maat (also personified as a goddess), which combined the ideas of order, truth, justice, and balance.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is papyrus?
reference-answers: a writing material like paper that could be rolled into scrolls and stored as records.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why did the pyramids serve as tombs for pharaohs of Egypt?
reference-answers: The preservation of the body was important and was directly related to Egyptian religious beliefs that a person was composed of a number of different elements.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is the Ba, according to Egyptian religious beliefs?
reference-answers: The Ba was also a type of spiritual essence, but it separated from the body after death, going out in the world during the day and returning to the body each night.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is a Ka?
reference-answers: A persons Ka was their spiritual double.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: How did the Ba separate from the body after death?
reference-answers: The Ba was also a type of spiritual essence, but it separated from the body after death, going out in the world during the day and returning to the body each night.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is the significance of the Ahk?
reference-answers: The duty of the Ahk, yet another type of spirit, was to travel to the underworld and the afterlife.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is the estimated workforce employed in constructing the pyramid of Khufu?
reference-answers: Excavations at the site reveal that these workers lived in cities built nearby that housed them as well as many others dedicated to feeding and caring for them. The workers were not enslaved, as is commonly assumed. Indeed, they likely enjoyed a higher standard of living than many other Egyptians at the time.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the outcome of the decentralization of power during the First Intermediate Period?
reference-answers: From the perspective of the reigning noble families, this may have seemed like chaos and disorder. But it was not necessarily the dark age older generations of historians believed it to be.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Who assumed control in Egypt around 1991 BCE, marking the end of the First Intermediate Period?
reference-answers: In the year 1991 BCE, Amenemhat, a former vizier (adviser) to the line of kings who established the Middle Kingdom, assumed control and founded a line of pharaohs who ruled Egypt for two centuries.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the name of the deity Amon-Re, which was introduced during the Middle Kingdom Period?
reference-answers: He was portrayed as the king of the gods and the father of each reigning pharaoh. The .pharaohs of the Middle Kingdom no longer constructed massive pyramids for their tombs. Instead, they focused on erecting massive temples to Amon-Re and his wife, the mother-goddess Mut, at Thebes ( Figure 3.22 ).

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Who was the powerful warrior pharaoh during whose reign Middle Kingdom Egypt reached its height?
reference-answers: Middle Kingdom Egypt reached its height in the 1870s and 1860s BCE during the reign of Senusret III, a powerful warrior pharaoh and capable administrator of the centralized state.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the name of the region that brought Egypt access to gold and mercenaries?
reference-answers: Kush was known for its rich gold deposits and capable warriors, and Senusret IIIs several campaigns there brought Egypt access not only to the gold but also to mercenaries from Kush.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the name of the mother-goddess worshipped alongside Amon-Re?
reference-answers: He was portrayed as the king of the gods and the father of each reigning pharaoh. The .pharaohs of the Middle Kingdom no longer constructed massive pyramids for their tombs. Instead, they focused on erecting massive temples to Amon-Re and his wife, the mother-goddess Mut, at Thebes ( Figure 3.22 ).

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What happened to the royal power after Senusret III and his son Amenemhat III died?
reference-answers: The deaths of Senusret III and his son Amenemhat III led indirectly to a rare but not unprecedented transfer of royal power to an Egyptian woman.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why did Sobekneferu's reign end?
reference-answers: Because she died without having had children, she was the last in the long series of pharaohs in the line of Amenemhat I.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What groups started to assert control over parts of Egypt?
reference-answers: The Semitic-speaking peoples from the Levant, possibly the result of increased trade between Egypt and the Levant at first.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the outcome of the Second Intermediate Period?
reference-answers: The territory once controlled by the powerful centralized state bureaucracy was effectively split into three regions: one ruled by Hyksos in the north, one by Kushite in the south, and one by the remnants of the Egyptian nobility in the center.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What happened to the relationships between the regions during the Second Intermediate Period?
reference-answers: For most of this period, the three regions of Egypt appear to have maintained peaceful relationships. That changed, however, beginning in the 1550s BCE when a string of Theban Egyptian .rulers was able to go on the offensive against the Hyksos.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: When did the Indus Valley Civilization emerge?
reference-answers: in the early third millennium BCE

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What type of agriculture was adopted by the farmers of the Indus valley civilization?
reference-answers: agriculture from the Near East, including barley and wheat cultivation techniques

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: When did the people of the Indus valley develop some agriculture techniques independently?
reference-answers: by about 5000 BCE

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is the approximate time period for the rise and fall of the Indus Valley Civilization?
reference-answers: c. 2800 BCE1800 BCE

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is the approximate population of the two largest cities in the Indus valley civilization at their height?
reference-answers: At their height, they likely had populations of about thirty thousand people each.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why did archaeologists initially not know about the Indus valley civilization until the early nineteenth century?
reference-answers: Because Harappa was the first major site discovered by archaeologists, the term Harappan often appears as a synonym for Indus valley civilization.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is believed to be the possible structural organization of the Indus valley cities?
reference-answers: It is equally plausible, however, that the few large cities functioned as regional capitals ruling over the surrounding smaller ones.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What does the division into two sections of a city in the Indus valley civilization likely represent?
reference-answers: All the cities are divided into two sections: a lower city that was largely a residential area, and an upper city or citadel that was walled off from the rest of the settlement.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was the typical structure of an Indus valley city?
reference-answers: The lower sections of the Indus valley cities consisted of residential quarters and workshops.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: Why do archaeologists believe ritual specialists lived in the citadels?
reference-answers: This evidence suggests that ritual specialists, perhaps priests, lived and performed religious functions in the citadels that may have required them to bathe in the large public bath and congregate in the hall.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was found at the site of Kalibangan?
reference-answers: Archaeologists uncovered a pit on top of the platform containing burned cattle bones.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What type of goods were imported from the Indus Valley into Mesopotamia?
reference-answers: Cuneiform tablets from Mesopotamia refer to the Indus valley as Meluhha and document that precious stones such as lapis lazuli and carnelian, as well as marine shells from the Indian Ocean, were imported from there.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is unique about the script on Indus Valley seals?
reference-answers: The script that appears on many of the seals is unique to the people of the Indus valley civilization, and scholars have yet to decipher it. It seems to consist of phonograms, signs for the sounds of syllables, and there appear to be about four hundred such signs.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: How did merchants from the Indus Valley export goods?
reference-answers: Merchants traveled by sea across the Indian Ocean and by land over the Iranian plateau.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: How did the Indus Valley Civilization decline?
reference-answers: Beginning around 1800 BCE, the centuries of trade between the Indus valley and Mesopotia came to an end. Over the next four centuries, the cities of the Indus River valley were slowly depopulated, and the civilization declined, likely in stages.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What is believed to be a possible cause for the decline of the Indus Valley Civilization?
reference-answers: One common view is that it was related to regional climate change.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What theory suggests that the decline of the Indus Valley Civilization was related to regional climate change?
reference-answers: Changes in the pattern of seasonal wind and rainfall, known as the monsoon in South Asia, may have caused these environmental effects.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: How did some scholars interpret the descriptions of the Aryans attacking the walled cities and forts of the indigenous population in religious literature?
reference-answers: While some of these descriptions were likely developed centuries after the fall of the Indus valley civilization and may be unrelated to it, some scholars continue to hold that these passages describe the conquest of Mohenjo-Daro.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What evidence supports the theory that Mohenjo-Daro was attacked around 1500 BCE and mostly destroyed?
reference-answers: Archaeological evidence attesting to the fact that Mohenjo-Daro was attacked around 1500 BCE and mostly destroyed lends some credibility to these claims.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: When did Mohenjo-Daro get attacked?
reference-answers: Archaeological evidence attesting to the fact that Mohenjo-Daro was attacked around 1500 BCE and mostly destroyed lends some credibility to these claims.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What may have caused the collapse of the Indus valley civilization?
reference-answers: A few or all these causes may have played a role. For example, environmental degradation caused by years of resource exploitation and high population density certainly had an effect.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: When did the social and political systems of Mohenjo-Daro break down?
reference-answers: However it happened, by around 1500 BCE, the social and political systems had broken down, and the sophisticated culture of the Indus valley civilization had collapsed.

world-history/chapter03-Early-Civilizati.question: What was abandoned in the cities of Mohenjo-Daro after their collapse?
reference-answers: The architectural styles that characterized the cities at their height were abandoned, as was the writing system, the sophisticated metalworking, and other artisanal crafts.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the starting point for the Iron Age in the Near East?
reference-answers: At the dawn of the Iron Age, which began around 1200 BCE in the Near East,

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Who built Mesopotamia's first empire approximately 2300 BCE?
reference-answers: When Sargon of Akkad built Mesopotamias first empire in approximately 2300 BCE,

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the outcome for the Third Dynasty of Ur?
reference-answers: By around 2004 BCE, all that remained of Ibbi-Sins empire was the city of Ur itself. In that year, it too was sacked by the Elamites and others.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the name of the Amorite chieftain who took Babylon in 1894 BCE?
reference-answers: In 1894 BCE, an Amorite chieftain named Sumu-adum took the city and installed himself as ruler.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the name given to Babylon by its founders?
reference-answers: it Bab-ili, which meant gateway of the gods.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did Hammurabi form an alliance with the Assyrians?
reference-answers: Early in his reign, Hammurabi made an alliance with the powerful Assyrians to the north.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Where did the Hittites originate?
reference-answers: Their precise origins are not known, but they were likely immigrants to Anatolia who blended into the local population and adopted much of its culture and religion.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the result of the Battle of Qadesh?
reference-answers: Generally accepted as a draw or possibly a narrow Hittite victory, the fighting at Qadesh is most memorable for ultimately leading the two forces to recognize that they had more to gain from peace than war.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What event marked the beginning of the Neo-Assyrian Empire?
reference-answers: It was only around 900 BCE that Assyria was able to reestablish control over northern Mesopotamia.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What two powers eventually overthrew the Neo-Assyrian Empire?
reference-answers: Beginning in the last decades of the seventh century BCE, two growing powers threatened and eventually overthrew Assyria. These kingdoms were Babylonia and Media.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What event occurred in 616 BCE that encouraged the Median dynasty to risk its own attack into Assyria?
reference-answers: Although the attack failed, it encouraged the Median dynasty to risk its own attack into Assyria.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the outcome of Nebuchadnezzar's invasion of Egypt in 601 BCE?
reference-answers: Then, in 601 BCE, Nebuchadnezzar attempted a bold invasion of Egypt itself, only to be repulsed by strong resistance.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the result of the Babylonian-Median alliance against Assyria?
reference-answers: Assyria received support from Egypt, but it was unable to prevent the Babylonian-Median alliance from overwhelming its forces and capturing its cities.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did ambassadors carry gifts when sent to another kingdom?
reference-answers: When sent to another kingdom, emissaries frequently carried with them an offering of high value for the king who received them, and on their return home, their king expected a present of equal or greater worth.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the purpose of establishing a special intelligence bureau in Mari?
reference-answers: Not only did he [Hammurabi] recruit agents of all types to keep tabs on other kings, but he even established a special intelligence bureau in the palace at Mari to collect, translate, and analyze documents provided by his many spies.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What could happen if an ambassador's king refused to supply an appropriate gift?
reference-answers: Occasionally an ambassador might be unable to return home, either because the relationship between the two kingdoms had gone sour or because the foreign king refused to supply an appropriate gift.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did kings in Mesopotamia prefer to avoid war if possible?
reference-answers: Kings preferred to avoid war if possible and maintain healthy diplomatic relationships with others instead.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What types of people were often employed as spies in Ancient Mesopotamia?
reference-answers: These could be merchants, sailors, artisans, or refugees fleeing foreign lands.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why was using spies risky for the rulers of Ancient Mesopotamia?
reference-answers: The very nature of the work suggested that such agents were never to be trusted, and betrayal was always a possibility.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What challenges did travelers face when traveling on long-distance roads in Ancient Mesopotamia?
reference-answers: They could expect some form of protection from local rulers, however, in exchange for paying custom fees and duties.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the primary concern of empires in the Near East regarding trade?
reference-answers: Access to foreign goods and raw materials was a major concern of empires in the Near East.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What types of goods did Assyrian traders trade in during the Old Assyrian period?
reference-answers: Assyrian traders traveled between Mesopotamia, Anatolia, and even Afghanistan trading in valuable goods like copper, tin, and textiles.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why were copper and tin especially important to the Assyrians?
reference-answers: Copper and tin were especially important because they are the ingredients needed to make bronze, the primary material for manufacturing metal tools and weapons in this period.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What social class was required to pay a fine if a noble injured a commoner?
reference-answers: However, a noble who injured a commoner could expect to merely pay a fine.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: How did the treatment of women under the law differ based on their husband's social class?
reference-answers: For example, if a husband divorced his wife because she had not given birth to sons, he was required to return her dowry and pay her a sum equal to the bride price paid upon marriage.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What type of housing were commoners' dwellings typically made of?
reference-answers: Commoners dwellings were typically windowless and made of mud with thick walls that protected the occupants from the oppressive summer heat.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was unique about the homes of the wealthy in Babylon during this period?
reference-answers: The homes of the wealthy, by contrast, were larger structures built around a central courtyard and included several rooms for different purposes, such as kitchens, bathrooms, reception rooms, and storage rooms.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What were the homes of the wealthy typically built around?
reference-answers: The homes of the wealthy, by contrast, were larger structures built around a central courtyard.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Who was elevated to the highest tier of the pantheon during Hammurabi's dynasty?
reference-answers: During Hammurabis dynasty, the storm god Marduk was elevated to the highest tier of the pantheon and accepted as the patron god of Babylonia.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What were the four hierarchically organized classes of the Assyrian population?
reference-answers: The Assyrian population was made up of four hierarchically organized classes: the nobility, the professional class, the peasantry, and the enslaved.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was believed to be consumed by the gods during temple rituals?
reference-answers: The temple staff also participated in elaborate religious festivals performed in the cities, such as the New Year Festival. During these events, the divine images of the gods were carried from the temples and throughout the town in a grand procession where everyone might catch a glimpse of the deity.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What were the four hierarchically organized classes in Assyrian society?
reference-answers: The Assyrian population was made up of four hierarchically organized classes: the nobility, the professional class, the peasantry, and the enslaved.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What role did priests play in the Assyrian empire?
reference-answers: Priests were important not only as interpreters of divine will but also as points of connection between the center of political power and the rest of the empire.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the social status of those enslaved by war?
reference-answers: At the very bottom of the social order were the enslaved, the majority of whom had been captured during war.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What were the consequences of defying the Assyrian war machine?
reference-answers: Those who defied the Assyrian war machine could expect swift and devastating consequences, including public torture and mutilation to demonstrate the price of rebellion (a response scholars have called calculated frightfulness).

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the purpose of deporting entire populations in Assyrian society?
reference-answers: Another tactic to shut down regular or particularly difficult rebellions was the forced.deportation of entire populations to other parts of the empire.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What were the economic conditions like in Hittite society?
reference-answers: With the exception of some leased acreage, village land was mostly held in common and worked by the people.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What prompted the early Hyksos to leave Canaan?
reference-answers: It is not entirely clear to historians what prompted these Hyksos to leave Canaan, but some suspect they were driven into Egypt by foreign invasion of their land.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What event marked the beginning of the Second Intermediate Period?
reference-answers: This transformation coincided with the onset of the Second Intermediate Period (c. 17201540 BCE) and the general collapse of centralized Egyptian rule.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: When did the Hyksos assume control of the entire delta?
reference-answers: Then, around 1650 BCE, one group of recently arrived Canaanites challenged the remaining princes, overthrew them, and assumed control of the entire delta, inaugurating an important new period in Egyptian history.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Who were the key leaders that held onto power during this period?
reference-answers: During this period, several Egyptian princes held onto power despite the changes occurring around them.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Who were the Hyksos?
reference-answers: These Canaanites are often referred to as the Hyksos.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What technological advancements did the Hyksos bring to Egypt?
reference-answers: They introduced composite-bow technology, new types of protective armor, and most importantly, the horse-drawn, lighter-weight chariot with spoked wheels.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: How did the Hyksos' rule affect Egypt?
reference-answers: Hyksos rule appears to have benefited Egypt in a number of ways.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the extent of the Hyksos' political power beyond Egypt?
reference-answers: though the extent of the Hyksos political power beyond Egypt was likely limited to a few city-states in Palestine, if that.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What event marked the end of the Hyksos kingdom?
reference-answers: By approximately 1540 BCE, Pharaoh Ahmose I had broken the defenses around Avaris, destroyed the Hyksos kingdom, and reasserted Egyptian power in Lower Egypt.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the name of the period that represented the pinnacle of Egyptian power and influence?
reference-answers: The New Kingdom period (c. 15501069 BCE) represents the pinnacle of Egyptian power and influence in the Near East.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why was it risky for Theban Egyptian rulers to try to oust the Hyksos?
reference-answers: However, an alliance between the Hyksos and the kingdom of Kush in the far south made any effort to oust the Hyksos extremely risky.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the result of Pharaoh Ahmose I's campaign against the Hyksos?
reference-answers: He then turned his attention south to Kush and east to Palestine, extending Egyptian control over these regions as well.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was notable about the Pharaohs of the New Kingdom?
reference-answers: Many came to power at a young age and ruled for an extended period of time that allowed for many accomplishments.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Who is Thutmose III?
reference-answers: The son married his sister Hatshepsut, who gave birth to a daughter but not a son. So when Thutmose II died in 1479 BCE, his two-year-old son conceived by a concubine assumed the throne as Thutmose III.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What is notable about Hatshepsut's claim to power?
reference-answers: Hatshepsut inaugurated a very unusual period in Egyptian history. Rather than merely rule in the background as a typical regent would, she proclaimed herself co-regent with her stepson and soon assumed the title of pharaoh.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did Hatshepsut wear masculine features on statues?
reference-answers: Such masculine features were not an attempt to obscure her femininity but rather a recognition that all the symbolic representations of Egyptian pharaohs were male.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What is notable about Hatshepsut's claim to divinity?
reference-answers: As Egyptian pharaohs had done for many centuries, Hatshepsut also claimed divinity.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did Hatshepsut have masculine features?
reference-answers: Such masculine features were not an attempt to obscure her femininity but rather a recognition that all the symbolic representations of Egyptian pharaohs were male.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What happened to Hatshepsut's statues and monuments after Thutmose III took control?
reference-answers: He had Hatshepsuts statues toppled and smashed, her name removed from monuments, and references to her scrubbed from the official king lists.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did Thutmose III erase Hatshepsut's memory?
reference-answers: The evidence suggests that he harbored no ill will toward his stepmother. Instead, her erasure from the record was probably part of Thutmoses process of paving the way for his son to rule in his own right in the future, without a dominant female like his stepmother to assert control.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What were some notable achievements during Amenhotep III's nearly forty-year reign?
reference-answers: These included the sumptuous palace at Thebes, the Serapeuma temple of the god Serapisat Saqqara, many temples for other gods, Amenhoteps own large mortuary temple, and a great many statues of himself.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was notable about Amenhotep IV's reign and the city he built?
reference-answers: Under Amenhotep IIIs heir Amenhotep IV, the emphasis on Aton reached its fullest extent. Amenhotep IV built a new city downriver from Thebes that he called Amarna, the place where the solar orb is transformed.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What changes did Amenhotep IV make to his name and the worship of Egyptian gods?
reference-answers: The following year, he changed his own name to Akhenaten, meaning the transfigured spirit of the solar orb, and moved himself and his entire family to the new city.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did Akhenaten close the temples of other major Egyptian gods?
reference-answers: Akhenaten later closed the temples of the other major Egyptian gods and ordered representations of them destroyed and their names chiseled off monuments.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the main reason for Akhenaten's new monotheistic religion?
reference-answers: Many theories have been proposed to explain Akhenatens motive for founding a new monotheistic religion, including sincere belief, but most have been discarded.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did the Egyptians attempt to erase the period of Akhetaton from their history?
reference-answers: One reason many questions about him remain is that after Akhenaten died in about 1336 BCE, Egyptians reverted to their older religious traditions and attempted to erase this period from their history.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the significance of Ramesses II's long reign?
reference-answers: The greatest pharaoh of this period, and the last great pharaoh of the New Kingdom, was Ramesses II, who ruled Egypt for more than sixty-five years from 1279 to 1213 BCE.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What were the main achievements of the Ramesside kings?
reference-answers: His heirs, sometimes called the Ramesside kings , worked hard to restore Egypt to greatness through impressive military and building campaigns.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the significance of Qadesh in Ramesses II's wars?
reference-answers: In an attempt to push them back and restore Egyptian influence in Syria, Ramesses II led an army of twenty thousand into Syria to retake the important city of Qadesh.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was Ramesses II's reason for leading an army into Syria?
reference-answers: In an attempt to push them back and restore Egyptian influence in Syria, Ramesses II led an army of twenty thousand into Syria to retake the important city of Qadesh.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did the threat from the Hittites motivate Ramesses II to build a new capital?
reference-answers: The threat they continued to pose also motivated him to build a new capital in the Nile delta, much closer to Canaan.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was unique about the temple built by Ramesses II at Abu Simbel?
reference-answers: The engineers who designed the temple constructed it such that twice a year, the rays of the sun would enter the building at dawn and bathe the gods placed there in light.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was one of Thutmose III's goals for his campaigns in Canaan?
reference-answers: By campaigning in Canaan several times, Thutmose III was able to bring the Canaanite regions back into Egypts orbit.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did Mitanni's rise lead some Canaanite leaders to seek its protection?
reference-answers: The rise of Mitanni led a number of Canaanite leaders who had previously pledged their allegiance to Egypt to instead seek Mitanni protection.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the outcome of the Battle of Qadesh?
reference-answers: The Battle of Qadesh was at best a draw.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did Egypt launch campaigns into the eastern Mediterranean regions of Canaan and Syria?
reference-answers: The value of these trade routes and commercial centers prompted Egypt to launch several campaigns into the area.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What were some of the main trade goods transported by Egypt to other parts of the world?
reference-answers: Trade goods coming from Egypt to other parts of the world included pottery, grains, papyrus, linen, and many other items.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did Egypt's influence in the region decline by 1100 BCE?
reference-answers: Toward the end of the New Kingdom era, Egypts ability to maintain control over the trade routes in Canaan and Syria declined steadily.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What is believed to have happened to the migrants described as 'coming from the sea'?
reference-answers: One of the consequences of this larger civilizational decline was that large numbers of migrants, such as those who attacked the envoy, were sweeping across the eastern Mediterranean bringing chaos and destruction.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: How did Egypt protect its trade routes?
reference-answers: Egypt provided border protection, supervised toll roads, and generally ensured the safety of merchants.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Who were referred to as 'the Sea Peoples'?
reference-answers: An Egyptian inscription from 1208 BCE described them as coming from the sea, which has led modern scholars to refer to them as the Sea Peoples ( Figure 4.27 ).

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did the Mycenaean kingdoms in Greece and the Hittite kingdom in Anatolia suffer greatly?
reference-answers: The disruption took a toll on the region, however. The Mycenaean kingdoms in Greece and the Hittite kingdom in Anatolia suffered greatly and collapsed.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the effect of the Sea Peoples' migration on Egypt's control over Canaan?
reference-answers: The migrating Sea Peoples in Canaan greatly weakened Egypts control of the region.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was the approximate time period of arrival of nomadic Indo-European speakers in Persia?
reference-answers: The origins of the Persians are murky and stretch back to the arrival of nomadic Indo-European speakers in the Near East, possibly as early as 2000 BCE.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Who was Cyrus II, also called Cyrus the Great?
reference-answers: According to Herodotus, Persia was made a vassal of Media in the seventh century BCE but freed itself in the sixth century BCE under the leadership of Cyrus II, also called Cyrus the Great.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was one notable military innovation introduced by Cyrus II?
reference-answers: Once in power, he reorganized the Persian state and its military to mirror those of the Median Empire. This step included creating divisions for cavalry, archers, and infantry and setting up special training for the cavalry.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Who was chosen by Cyrus as governors for his empire?
reference-answers: Cyrus generally selected from local areas, a prudent move in a world where rebellions were common.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did the invading Egyptians retreat up the Nile but was captured by Cambyses II?
reference-answers: The defending Egyptians were soon overwhelmed, and the pharaoh retreated up the Nile but was captured.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was a common practice of Persian expansion that helped win support in newly acquired areas?
reference-answers: This practice of respecting local traditions was acommon feature of Persian expansion and helped to win support in newly acquired areas.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What led to the rise of possibly Persias most famous and powerful leader, Darius I?
reference-answers: On his way to put down the rebellion, Cambyses II died, leaving the future of the empire uncertain but allowing for the rise of possibly Persias most famous and powerful leader, Darius I.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What happened during the palace coup that led to Darius becoming king?
reference-answers: Afterward, since neither Cambyses nor Bardiya had sons, Darius made himself king.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: Why did some scholars speculate about Darius inventing the story about a false Bardiya?
reference-answers: Other accounts differ in some ways, and some scholars have speculated that Darius invented the story about a false Bardiya in order to legitimize his own coup against the real Bardiya and take the throne.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was one of the first tasks for Cambyses II after becoming king?
reference-answers: The first task for Cambeses was to continue preparing for the invasion of Egypt his father had planned.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What happened to the Persian Empire after Darius I's coup?
reference-answers: We may never know exactly what happened, but Darius was indeed able to grasp control of the Persian Empire in 522 BCE.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: How did Darius I strengthen his claim on the throne?
reference-answers: To further strengthen his claim on the throne, Darius integrated himself deeply into the royal line through a number of marriages.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: How did Darius I organize the Persian Empire?
reference-answers: Darius now set about reorganizing the empire, carving it into twenty different governing districts called .satrapies.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What was unique about the organization of the Persian heartland?
reference-answers: The only area not made into a satrapy was the Persian heartland, which was governed directly by the king.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: How were letters transmitted along the royal roads?
reference-answers: action between the satraps and the king was carried out through letters dictated to scribes and transmitted along royal roads.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: What type of infrastructure project did Darius undertake that would have allowed ships to pass from the Red Sea into Egypt's Nile River?
reference-answers: For example, he ordered the construction of a long canal that would have allowed ships to pass from the Red Sea into Egypts Nile River and thus to the Mediterranean.

world-history/chapter04-The-Near-East/te.question: How did the workers who built palaces under Darius' reign migrate?
